That being said the "German Food" at this restaurant didn't impress.  I don't think I will ever go out of my way to eat German food again. To be fair the Giant Pretzel was amazing. The sausage sampler was delicious. But aside from that, the food seemed kinda bland. The breaded protein with the crispy potatoes is called The schnitzel you have a choice of chicken veil and pork. That was ok. German pasta is called Spätzle, it has a different texture but it was bland didn't have any flavor to it. Deserts were delicious we had the  chocolate cake and the cherry   I was not aware that this restaurant had been on TV. I guess one of Guy Fieri shows filmed and reviewed this restaurant. Good for them. If you're close by stop in and have a pretzel and a beer. Skip the menu.

#WVFN rolled in to Haus Murphy's last night.

For starters, they have proper 32oz glasses, so they're already a hit in my book.

Started the eating part of the night with a couple giant pretzels.

Giant is correct; the thing was as big as my head! And big, puffy, salty, and delicious! With the brown mustard, it was definitely a hit!

We ordered the Bauernplatte, which is listed as a combo for two, but handily accommodated three of us.

The schnitzel was delicious, the german fried potatoes were delicious, bratwurst was ok.

I avoided the red cabbage because I'm not a fan, but the other diners stated it was fantastic.

Beer:
Weihenstephan Hefeweizen was everything a wheat beer should be; rich and full-bodied, but not too heavy, with a very light citrus attribute.

Franziskaner Weissbier was phenomenal! Delicious, rich, perfect.

Franziskaner Dunkel was superb.

Can't wait to sample the remainder of their selections.

The live music was really awesome.

They have a nice patio, with misters, so even in the summer it should be pleasant.

I would never have guessed a place like this existed in Glendale. Now that I'm aware of its existence, I will certainly try to return.

It took me a while to realize my vision of dining at Haus Murphy's. I first became aware of them from watching Diners, Drive-Ins & Dives on Food Network. In fact, I stole their paprika gravy recipe when hosting an Oktoberfest dinner party at my house. It was delicious over home-cooked schnitzel. I had to guess on amounts of ingredients, since Guy Fieri does the superfast play-by-play on the cooking process, but it worked out just fine. So I'm quite familiar with German food and have even pickled and cooked my own sauerbraten (sour beef roast). I had to try the sauerbraten at Haus Murphy's!

In a nutshell, I have to say that Haus Murphy's has delicious, authentic-tasting German food. The rotkohl (red cabbage) is right-on-the-money and the sauerkraut is truly fabulous. The sauerbraten was also very good... tender, slow-cooked, and thinly-sliced with just enough twang to wake you up. My buddy ordered the steamed smoked pork chops which were porkaliciously snarfable.

I do have some critical notes on what didn't work, however. The spätzle (mini noodle/dumplings) were uninteresting and watery. Didn't have the remarkable fluffy but chewy texture I expected (and yes, I've made my own spätzle). The sauerbraten, while delicious, simply suffered from being too tiny of a portion. I think even if they charged an extra buck or two, it would be worth it, but this was not a fair dinner-size portion. My buddy even had pity on me and let me share his pork chops (which were a generous portion).

So five stars for food and service and beer selection, but I have to hold back one star for residual hunger pangs. I will definitely be back to dine here again. But if I want to get full next time, I'm gonna load up on the pork! (As you may not know, pork is considered a vegetable in Germany...)

This IS as good as it gets for authentic German food in Arizona.

I went here with a large party for my birthday dinner. We called ahead and they were very accommodating. We enjoyed a variety of absolutely delicious cold beers to start it off in large 1 liter glasses. Schnitzel was crunchy and delicious, and I sampled the jaegerschnitzel as well that my wife had. Also phenominal. 

For my birthday was was serenaded by an accordian player in German. I don't speak any German, so he may have been saying anything, but it was unique and very fun. Split tabs was not a problem and the staff was on top of serving us. 

I can't wait to go back! Easy to run up a big bill though with all the delicious food and beer, but it was worth the money.

Been going here for years, even before they moved to their current location. We went for dinner on 06/25/2016. I ordered my favorite beer and it was warm and a little flat. The schnitzel appeared to have been cooked at a previous time and reheated in the microwave. We got a slice of the chocolate sauerkraut cake, as we always do. The slices keep getting smaller every time we go. This time it did not taste the same as it used to. The cake was not as dense as it used to be and lacked something.
I think the place has passed its prime and that is very unfortunate.
If you are going to skimp to save a buck, you should just close the business. It's better to go out of business leaving your long time customers with good memories rather than bad ones.

Haus Murphy's is Old World charm in the middle of historic Glendale.  But it sure isn't the place for vegetarians! And while knew I would be surrounded by wiener schnitzels, I also thought I'd be able to find something I could eat.  And I did, but barely! 
They have a cheese schnitzel, literally the ONLY meatless thing I could find on the menu, but it was good.  The potato dumplings are really tasty too.

I think this place is worth a visit, even if you don't eat meat, you can have the cheese schnitzel and a humungous beer and feel like you're in Germany for the day!

Where else can you sit outside for a nice lunch, guaranteed shade, full bar, and feel like you're back in Germany - Haus Murphy's.  We were greeted by a nice German lady who warned us of a couple of sweat bees that were wanting a taste a beer but weren't interested in the people.   No bother.  They left us alone.  Lunch was great!  I had a daily special sandwich that was hackbraten on grilled rye bread.  I can't remember what it was called.  My hubs is a sucker for Sauerbraten.  Also ordered a plate of potato pancakes.  

Best pancakes we have found, ever. 

My mom and step dad aren't impressed with this place as they used to be and they live in the area but I had to see for myself.  It's too bad their experiences aren't what we had.  We loved it.  Also tried the new Schoffhofer grapefruit beer.  I am on the hunt for this stuff now.  It's so good!   I handed my hubs the keys and ordered another.  Too bad we cannot get the beer here in Michigan.  The bill was a little hefty but we weren't watching it and it was worth the wonderful afternoon of leisurely lunching with the old folks on a weekday afternoon. 

There isn't a large selection of German restaurants in the Valley but you don't need anymore more when you have Haus Murphy in downtown Glendale.

I attended a UYE (Unofficial Yelp Event) here and I have to say that Haus Murphy's pretty much wowed all 20 or so of us!

It has taken me over a week to get to the review.  I was still reflecting on the German meatloaf, red cabbage and Weihenstephaner Hefeweizen.

How do you say, "Damn that was good!" in German?  I have new found respect for German cuisine thanks to Chef Hoffman (not sure about the spelling there).

The fubar of Yelpers (I am pretty sure that is the correct term for a large gathering of Yelpers) dined on the patio which is a great space.  Service was very good throughout the meal.

There was quite a bit of sharing going on and although I don't remember everything I tried, it was all really good.

It was great to see so many friends and meet some new Yelpers like Norm!
Good place to get your oompapa on.  Liters of beer, real german food.  Little pricey but worth it.  Will be back again.  Indoor and outdoor seating in a nice part of town.

I was walking with the family by Glendale Glitters and noticed Haus was right down the street. My sister loved the pretzels there, so we went.

The staff didn't look to busy for a Sunday evening and they took a good 10 minutes to even greet us, which bugged me a bit. After they finally greeted us, the female hostess got mad at us for seating ourselves. But we just listened to the guy up front and he told to seat ourselves,  which we explained to the female. 

Now to the food. I don't know if it is cause I'm Mexican, but the food was very bland and tasteless. The pretzel was only okay at best. The other thing we ordered was the stuffed mushrooms and you can only taste the mushroom itself. Where's the sausage and other flavors?

Safe to say, I won't be returning to this place.

Went there after seeing it DD&D.  Waiter barely gave us time to look over the menu, then took his time coming back to take our order. Not even a crust of bread on the table to begin with. We ordered the sausage sampler and potato pancake. Very average and overpriced for sausage. We ordered sauerbraten to share and glad we didn't order anything else. The meat was tough, bland and was not cooked in any sauce to make it tender. Thick cut slabs with sauce poured over top. I expected fork tender and this was just plain awful. Staff never asked us how our food was and had to flag down waiter for another drink. Will not be back.

Amazing, authentic German cuisine! This is my go-to restaurant, and is well worth any line to get in! Even the dessert is to die for. The servings are huge and you will definitely go home with left overs! My first time here was with my boyfriend. We shared the biggest plate they had, trying a little of everything they had. We had food to go, and we even got dessert to go! You will love the authentic feel of the restaurant, from the music, to the pub. Must go to!

HOW IN THE WORLD HAVE I NEVER REVIEWED THIS PLACE? Yes, triple D brought me here but amazing food (and beer) is what keeps me coming back. If you've never been you must get the sampler for two. Gives you a chance to try everything. I am obsessed with all of the schnitzel, red cabbage, sauerkraut and basically everything on the menu. The soup of the day is always a hit... Oh we also love the pretzel with cheese, like I will fight someone over the last piece of that. And of course the sauerkraut cake is like nothing you have ever had. Delish. Take it to go because you're going to be stuffed after your meal. Love the choices of German beers. It's always a treat to come here, what other place could impress a full blooded German girl?

Unfortunately I had never tried Authentic German food before and there was nothing to eat here for a person who is a vegetarian or a person looking for fresh vegetables. 
 I wish they would add something (even a small salad) for a person who is conscious of their eating habits, or doesn't eat meat/gluten.  The meats we're battered with flour and/or soaked in gravy. 
The beer was good.

I've been here twice, and as I am not a huge German food fan, I was a tad skeptical at first.  However, I was greeted by warm service.  They have a very authentic menu, and it tastes similar to some of the food that I had in Germany.  My family also loved their selection of beer and dessert.  While the food isn't to die for, it is authentic and pretty good.

First time dining here and it was a decent experience. Our server, Deb, I believe, as very nice and attentive despite the large parties and music playing.
My date and I split the platter for two and found most of it enjoyable. Bland in some spots, though. I travelled through Germany and was surprised at the blandness and yet, powerful sweetness in some of the items. 
I also thought the menu was really short; 2 appetizer choice, maybe 10 entrees. This seemed strange because I had read the menu on the way there and then saw none of the items I would have wanted on the limited menu. After reading another review (now, 5 hours since We were there) it looks like they limit the menu for Glendale Glitters. Would have helped to have known that before We got a sour taste in our mouths on the place already. 
We said we would be back, but certainly aren't counting down the days until then. Maybe for Oktoberfest

We enjoyed everything about Hauz Murphy. We weren't sure it would be authentic German food by the name but one look at the food and atmosphere and there was no mistake. We loved the Wienerschnitzel and the sauerbraten. And don't forget the pretzel. The mustard served with the  pretzel is the real thing (with just the perfect little bite to it). The pretzel fed four of us for an appetizer. The sauerkraut cake was so moist and loaded with fudge frosting!  We will be sure to come back and bring our friends!

Beer awesome soup ok both my wifes and my plates were awful. I had the plate Guy Furie had when his show was there tasted like a microwave dinner cabbage gross dumpling no flavor  my wife's tasted like Dinty More canned stew her spatzle awful too. Prices outrageous for quality service was a bright spot. May go back for beer and huge pretzel that's about it.

My husband and I went here for our second time just last night. The waiter was on point and the food was amazing. We sat outside and the it was perfect with music and great atmosphere. I was very impressed. We will be back. Thank you Haus Murphy's!

This place is great.  We went on a Friday night.  The food was excellent, service was great.  Angela was our server and made sure we never lacked drinks and that our food came out at a great, comfortable pace.  Great live German music and an excellent outdoor seating area.

And beer in 32oz steins.  Gotta love that!

Mien Gott, look no further for amazing German food. I've come here twice and will back come many more. The owner is amazingly personable and makes you feel like a priority even when the whole restaurant is full. Our server (I feel awful I don't remember his name but the blond one) was just as personable. He joked with us and was incredibly knowledgeable of the menu. We got to sit outside and really soak in the atmosphere, the polka music was a wonderful addition. No doubt we'll be back.

Fun, relaxed place with both indoor and outdoor dining. The menu isn't overly large but plent of different options. Portions are generous but not ridiculous.  A little worn at the seams but still a nice stop downtown.

Been there a few times.  I really enjoy eating outside.  Sometimes they have an outdoor musician.  

I've been to Germany and the food is legit, but it's not my favorite cuisine.  My wife is part German and absolutely LOVES this place.  Service was always great.

It's definitely not inexpensive.  We only go on rare special occasions.  The wait to get seated gets nuts during Octoberfest.  They do take reservations.

I highly recommend coming during holidays when Glendale Glitters is in full swing.
"Fantastic German food" is what I have heard from EVERY person I know who's ever been here. I agree. Every plate I tried was impressive. They also have some great rare German beers.

What a great place! Very cute, inside and out. We sat on the patio as the weather was beautiful. I was here with my family and this was our first time at Haus Murphy's. I'm always up for trying new things it was just a chore trying to get my dad to agree.
We started with the Sausage Sampler ($9.95) which was really good. The only thing that would have made it better is if we had another type of sausage. I don't consider 2 types of sausage to be a sampler platter.
I had the Schweizer Schnitzel ($14.95) which apparently is a Swiss traditional meal, tender Pork Loin wrapped with Emmenthaler Cheese and Black Forest Ham, breaded and sautéed with the Chef's Paprika Sauce (an extra $2)
It came with the German fried potatoes - which are fried in bacon grease. Everything was really REALLY good. Now the food all seems to be rather fragrant as you could smell all the great food everyone else was eating. I was expecting it to be very flavorful. Like an explosion of taste when I bit in. It was not. The tastes of everything were simple which I think I enjoyed more than I normally would have. I was able to concentrate and define various flavors a bit easier than normal I guess. It came with this creamy cabbage concoction which was superb! 
For dessert I had something that sounded truly disgusting but was WONDERFUL. The Sauerkraut cake. It is a rich moist chocolate cake without a hint of sauerkraut taste. mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.
I will definitely be back. I think this would be a fun place to go with a large group of people! Maybe next time I will have to try some of their beer and definitely the giant pretzel.
Oh and the waiter was superb. I think my mom even developed a little crush on him.

If you have ever eaten at an exceptional German restaurant, you will be ruined for life. Years ago, the Haus would have gotten 4 stars. But after being turned on to a little gem in Gibson City, IL called "The Bayrn Stube" my appreciation of fatty meat and spices stuffed in an intestine laid on a bed of sauerkraut and red cabbage has been forever changed. Haus just doesn't quite measure up. The cup of soup before the entree tasted like it came out of a can and the bread looked like the sheets of Hawaiian bread you buy at wally world. Probably the biggest turn off was when they brought out the brown mustard still in a plastic squeeze container. 
My meal was the Nuernberger/Kassler combo for one, and I had enough left over for breakfast the next day. Their sausages seem to be of lesser quality than I would get at Sunflower and the red cabbage had some pork gristle in it. Not that I mind a little pork fat in my cabbage, but not chunks, and definitely not gristle. My friend ordered the Huehner (Chicken) Schnitzel, which had a very good flavor, it was the best part of either of our meals. They do have a nice selection of good beers on tap, no Aventinus though. 
If the food was anything other than German, it would get 2 stars. It is nice to have somewhere to get a schnitzel when I'm in the area, but I wouldn't drive out of my way to eat here.

We went here based on the Food Network show (Guy Fieri) in hopes of having a fine German meal.  Unfortunately we were very disappointed in the food and the overall experience.

Upon arrival we were greeted and led past the more formal dining areas to the bar area in the back of the restaurant.  It is a large room set up with many long tables that seemed similar to a Bavarian beer hall.  The tables were covered with vinyl I guess to make cleanup easier.  Three or four other tables were occupied plus a few people at the bar.  I imagine the room would be much busier during Octoberfest. But we thought it was kind of cool since it did create an German like atmosphere.

Our waiter arrived and while he was not rude he certainly was not friendly and seemed like he would have preferred to be somewhere else that evening.  He did not make any recommendations or inform us of any specials. 

We ordered our meals and appetizers which were the Wienerschnitzel and Saurbraten along with one potato pancake appetizer and one pretzel.

The meal started out with a small cup of the soup of the day which was cabbage soup.  It came out slighty warm at best and was like a broth with a mild flavor and a few bits of cabbage.  Very bland and unimpressive start.

The meals came next and also were only slightly warm.  The sauerbraten consisted of thin slices of beef which was nothing like I remembered from visits to Germany. The flavor was mild and hard to understand why Guy Fieri raved so much about it on his show.  The Wienerschnitzel was greasier than I would have preferred but it was a huge serving that covered half the plate.  The German fried potatoes were good but would have been much better had they been hot.  The spatzel and red cabbage was as expected but unremarkable.

We finished the meal sharing a large slice of the Saurkraut cake which was the best part of the meal.  Overall the cost of the three entrees, two appetizers, one dessert and two small beers was $103 + tip.  

We came with high expectations (perhaps too high) and left somewhat disappointed.  I doubt we will return to this restaurant.

Killer schnitzel and liter mugs of Franziskaner. What more can you ask for? Excellent patio atmosphere--make sure to sit outside when the weather is nice. Love the tuba and accordion guys on the weekends!

I have been here 3-4 times and always enjoy it. Although I cannot enjoy the many schnitzel's (breaded and therefore not gluten free) my bf says they are wonderful. I myself usually get one of the many bratwursts they offer and have always been pleased. The German fried potatoes and the sauerkraut are outstanding! I usually start off with a Gewurztraminer wine and a friend usually gets a German beer. On a recent Saturday evening visit, a German 2-man band was playing to add to the ambiance. Our server was attentive but didn't hover. Always an enjoyable time here.

Every time I go to Spring Training, My wife and I stop at Haus Murphy's.  We went with some friends this past time.  The portions are generous and the food is fabulous.  We like the ambiance and there is plenty of parking in the back.  I recommend ordering the pretzel as a started, as good as it gets.   We noticed another couple ordering two to go so they could take them to a ball game.

I really like Haus Murhpy's.  A little taste of Germany in the middle of downtown historic Glendale.  The huge homemade soft pretzel with mustard is a must have for an appetizer.  Great German beer choices.  They serve a wheat beer with no hops.  Being allergic to hops, it's nice to have that option.  They have several schnitzels to choose from and the saurbraten is greatt.  Everything on the menu is tasty.  You have to try the sauerkraut chocolate cake for dessert.  The sauerkraut makes it so moist.  Trust me.   

This is comfort food.  You wont' find much in the way of diet foods here.  If that's what you're looking for, then you'll have to go elsewhere.  There are no gluten free items on the menu as far as I know.

Otherwise, I think you'll love it.  Quaint and homey.

[UPDATE] My December 2011 still stands pretty much as I wrote it then, minus just under a half star but not enough to take them down to 3-stars (yet). We have been to Haus Murphy's since 2011 but I wanted to do a quick update based on this, my December 2014 visit. This time we shared what the website describes as a single combination plate (the printed menu calls it something different) and the Roulade, which is described similarly to the online menu. We did that because we could get tastes of a bratwurst, a slightly smoked pink pork chop, the Roulade, German potatoes, sauerkraut, red cabbage and spaetzli.

Everything was okay. I liked the taste of the Roulade, if I didn't know what was supposed to be in it, which their menu states as filled with Pickle, Bacon and Onion; smothered with Golden Mustard. The reality is I could see, find nor taste any of the above. More like they mystery paste that's inside a Chef Boyardee Ravioli. It tasted fine but none of those flavors was present in any way, and it's pretty hard to hide the tastes of pickle, bacon, onion and mustard!

Instead of beer we opted for a nice hearty white wine. Some things have changed a bit over time ... the spaetzli was served plain, no gravy. The soup was much better but still served lukewarm. And some things haven't changed ... for example they still don't serve nor offer a bread plate. It's like they have no clue how meals are served in Germany and most of eastern Europe. Our server (Austin) was almost everything you would want in a server ... polite, attentive, upbeat and happy (as everyone at Haus Murphy seems to always be). On the downside, I would suggest he learn just a minimal amount about the very limited selection of wines they offer. His response to our basic wine questions was very deer-in-the-headlights.

My rating hasn't changed; they still are very good with the potential of earning 5-stars if they tried harder. The only (huge) negative that I won't grade them on is that whenever the front door is opened (about every 5 seconds) a frigid blast of cold air rushes in and quick-freezes everything on your plate. There has to be a better way, like build another door from the kitchen directly to the patio so they don't have to carry plated meals through the dining room (how hard could that be?). Until then I just wanted to yell "Murphy, Shut The Front Door!"

Final note ... NO restaurant anywhere that wants to be taken more seriously than a Denny's should EVER serve ice water in plastic Pepsi tumblers. For a sit-down restaurant that is a total fail.

We stopped in following a AKC dog show at Glendale Stadium.  I found Haus Murphy's on "petcentric.com" and called to ensure that they were open and were, in fact, dog friendly.  It was Easter and I also wanted to make sure that they would be open becuase it was only 11:00 a.m.  The woman who answered the phone said that they had a brunch, and although it was not fully set up yet, we were welcome to come by early.  She confirmed dogs were welcome in the beer garden (aka patio).  We arrived and were warmly greeted, they offered water and dog biscuits for my two girls, and also offered a special plate of "people food."  The buffet was terrific!  Great german specialities and my husband also enjoyed the roast beef.  The owner/chef came out and chatted with us.  It was an all-around terrific experience, and we will undoubtedly go back for the art walks and other events in Glendale just to visit this terrific restaurant.

I held off on this review, I was here on New Years Eve before heading to westgate and again this past week.  

The service is fantastic, the beer is great, and the food, well that has become really hit or miss.

I would love to 5 star this place because I grew up in the area and have been here dozens of times and it had been great.  But recent trips there have left me using the word "bland" a lot.  The pork schnitzel was flat out not good, and the spicy brat which was always one of my favorites here did not measure up either.  Worst of all, on my new years eve visit, they were "out" of the fried potatos and left us with average potato salad and french fries.

I'll probably be back, because I go to many downtown Glendale events, and have a little sentimental value in this place...but I sure hope it steps back up.
I went here on a date night, beautiful ambiance and fun restaurant...ALOT of meat meals to go around, purple cabbage was really good

Beer good! Atmosphere fun! Good place to eat outside if its a nice day.  Food good but overpriced.  I had snizle and it was ok but for the money not worth it.  The service was pretty good and the staff knowledgeable about German beers and food.  Its good to try once and that's bout it just to say you did.
So so so good!! Loved the food and the ambiance. Great service too! We've gone a few times now and each time is the same. Can't wait to go back!

Very nice time with friends and family! The food was good, the 32-oz beer was tasty and the atmosphere was pretty authentic (so I'm told. I never been to Germany.) 

I wasn't a fan of the cheese type soup and, like any normal person, I didn't like the sauer kraut. Otherwise, the sausage, German potatoes and wiener snitzel (sp?) were great!

The 32-oz beer was $11 and our meals were $14.95 each. All in all, not too bad at all.

Tried this place a few weeks back. I know almost nothing about German food so I took some time with the menu before ordering. Our server and all the staff we dealt with were all very nice and helpful with offering suggestions and answering questions. We ended up ordering a couple appetizers and pretty much the whole table ordered schnitzel of some kind. Everything was very good, though a couple of the sides weren't my thing, but I would have no problem going back here again for dinner. Also, everything I ate that was bread of some kind was outstanding. This place is a carb lover's paradise.

I love this place. Period. Nice atmosphere some life German music ( if u lucky) it's like a small piece of Germane in the heart of Glendale. Never was disappointed by the food we ordered. The only warning try not to "judge" them on Glendale glitters time. It is really crazy there. Tons of people. And menu on this period is really limited. To enjoy the food and atmosphere make a reservation on weekends also. 
Unfortunately I can't find a lot of things that I can eat there now since I became vegetarian/vegan ( no milk no meat) but they still could modify some of their dishes to accommodate my needs. Which I greatly appreciated! 
All food there is delicious but I was stuck on my meatloaf lol. Every time when we came I used to tell myself that I will order something else but every single time I cannot cheat on my favorite dish. Lol
I did grab a bite from my husbands plate every time and it's really good but my heart belongs to that meatloaf. 
I think that's one of the few things that I miss since I stopped eating meat. 
definitely recommend this place!

The prager schnitzel was pretty good very tasteful. If you were to start trying German food its a great place to start. I would recommend it to the beginner and the intermediate, but not for the hardcore German food lover.

Okay, this is for everyone who has complained about the limited menu during Glendale Glitters and the long wait time to be seated and served. First of all this is not a chain restaurant like Applebees or Chiles where the food is prepared in the midwest and shipped frozen to the restaurant. The menu is limited due to the volume of customers during the winter months. Try coming here during the Spring, Summer or Fall. The menu is expanded, to include the beer, and the crowds are much more tolerable. There are so many tables and chairs to accomodate diners so be patient, or come back another time, such as Spring, Summer or Fall. My wife and I have been coming here since they first opened, in their original location one block west of the current location. The original location was a lot smaller than the current location. They moved because of the overwhelming response of crowds loving the food and beer. 
We realize when we go during the winter months they won't have all of our favorite food and beer selections we normally get. We know they will be busy and the servers will do the best that they can.
If you were disappointed with the food, beer or service during Glendale Glitters, come back during the "off season" and you will not be disappointed. Thanks

Located in the heart of Downtown Glendale, this noisy little place caught our attention walking by. Now,  I am not German, nor do I even really know what German food is, but I was actually quite surprised and enjoyed my experience.  

We sat outside in what looks like an alley, where flags hung from above and where one space heaters warmed 2 tables. Nice and cozy. For two people we ordered the stuffed mushrooms, the giant pretzel, and the paprika schnitzel. This was surprisingly way more than enough food. The mushrooms were great! The we opted to get the pretzel with the extra cheese (~$3 more). I could have done without the horseradish tasting cold cheese in the tiny 2oz cup. I think I was expecting the warm yellow gooy cheese you normally find at the fair...heh. The paprika schnitzel we ordered because apparently Guy Ferrari from Food Network got it and it wasn't bad but not the best thing I've tasted in the world. Its giant fried piece of pork(?) with a side of green beans and german fries. 

Environment: 4/5
Food: 4/5
Price: 3/5 
Service: 5/5

We've been wanting to go here for several years, but every time we were in the area, they were out of food, or had a 2 hour wait.  This time, we arrived about 4:50pm to beat the dinner rush before Glendale Glitters.  We were seated immediately, but it took some time for our server to take our drink order.  Then quite some time before the drinks arrived.  After she dropped the drinks off, she left.  Again, quite some time later, she took our order.  One in our party had a hard time deciding.  Instead of possible suggestions, the server just stood there.  The prezels were amazing.  The beer cheese soup came out only lukewarm, but was good.  We advised our server of this issue and she seems uninterested.  Four of our 5 dishes arrived, but our youngest son's chicken strips did not arrive with the rest of the food.  We were told they would be "right out".  All our dishes were lukewarm.  We had to ask for refills on our sodas and waters.  Finally, after we were pretty much finished with our meals, my son's chicken strips arrived.  No apologies, no "let me take that off your ticket", no nothing.  Server was pretty much non-existent.  Of the dishes, the roulade was excellent, as was the goulash.  Spatzle was bland.  Chicken schnitzel was good.

After I secured the deal on my Bayern filly I was starving and thought to continue German traditions. 

The exterior looks absolutely fantastic! And so does the interior! With girls in German dress which looks very sexy :)

Now, there was a guy John who rocked! Patient, polite, funny and quick. He would tell stories to entertain customers.  His manner to bow was so elegant.
He is from Germany, so I was able to learn a little about that wonderful country.

I ordered the beef roulade and I loved it! I also liked how the portion was sized, not too big so I got no left overs.

It takes time for me to come back to the restaurants I've been to but I already want to visit that place again :)

Haus Murphy's is one of the only German cuisine restaurants in Arizona (as far as I know), and let me tell you, it's tops.

My experience there has been positive. The dining hall is split into three areas, each with it's own distinct feel. There's the bar, complete with accordion player and loads of German booze. The patio, which has a great Euro feel to it. And lastly, there's what I like to call the "breakfast" area, which is closest to the main entrance. 

These three distinct areas cover quite a bit of ground, and definitely add to the feel of the "German" experience. 

I have only had one dish the several times I've been to Murphy's, but that's all you really need from a place like this. My go-to meal is the Stuffed Mushrooms. These babies are HUGE, stuffed to the brim with fine german-style meat, The sauce they place them in is superb and ultimately makes it.

I would recommend Haus Murphy to anyone looking for something different in the metropolitan Phoenix area.

Whoa, totally don't understand the love for this place.  We met with a group over here and boy was I disappointed.  To begin, why doesn't Glendale have meters?  Why do I have to go out and move my car every two hours?  That makes it really hard to drink and sober up without drinking and driving if I have to go out and move my car to a new spot every 120 minutes.  That's not Haus Murphy's fault but it is something that will deter me from going out there to drink.  

So we get in there and our waitress is awesome enough.  She is friendly, responsive, and helpful.  In fact, I want that waitress to come with me to some other restaurants (looking at you Fez) and show them how it should be done.  In any event, she was great and the only saving grace of this establishment.

Now on to the bad food.  I'm not German, never been to Germany, and my German culinary knowledge is limited to Milwaukee Brewers' baseball games.  That being said, food either tastes good or it doesn't.  I had the Wullwurst sausages.  They came out looking like fried Twinkies and tasted about the same.  No spice, no real flavor, and surrounded by a tough skin.  They were flanked by some purple cabbage that was unedible and some German potato salad that was some of the nastiest mush I've ever had.  

Apparently unsatisfied by this gluttonous torture that I had already endured, I ordered the German chocolate cake.  Now, I know this isn't an actual German food but it looked good and I thought they might go all out with it.  Nope, again - not good.  Flavorless.  I was basic chocolate cake with a thin layer of coconut on top and some Betty Crocker frosting on the outside.  

Sorry but this place was just not good and I will not be back.

Haus Murphy's is an incredible experience! 

Some friends and I ate here before the Chocolate Affaire. I kind of wish we had just hung out here for the night instead! Delicious food, awesome entertainment and stellar patronage awaits you at Haus Murphhy's. If you aren't stuffed after your schnitzel, you need to try the sauerkraut chocolate cake. I will definitely be back!

Not much omm pa pa in this German restaurant. Ach du lieber. 

My dad was career military and our family was stationed in Heidelberg, Germany for several years, while I was a teenager. I was fortunate for many things, among them the ability to enjoy a wide variety of tasty and authentic German foods. I miss the German comfort food from my youth. 

That's why I was so excited to hear about Haus Murphy. Not only is it located nearby, in the Phoenix area, it has also been featured on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives - so it must be good, right? 

Well, actually, not so much. I ordered the Schweizer Schnitzel, pork loin with sliced ham and cheese. Sounds scrumptious, but was actually a bit dry and I'm not sure I could have detected the ham and cheese unless I knew it was (supposed to be) there. My husband had the Chicken Schnitzel with white wine mushroom sauce. Even though I'd never heard of chicken being made into a schnitzel, it was better than mine. Entrees include a side of German potatoes and also Wirsing (creamed cabbage) both good. In addition, we ordered a side of red cabbage (great) and also spatzle noodles (fair). 

The live omp pah band had good intentions, but was so loud it disturbed the customers.  I heard one customer ask the waiter to please move the band away from their table because it was making for an unpleasant dining experience.

Overall, nothing horrible, nothing great, I won't be returning.

On a Saturday evening, my husband & I went to Haus Murphy's .

The atmosphere was truly "Gemutlich" or friendly and warm. The service was great , our waiter was prompt, efficient and helpful.

The meal was Wunderbar! We started the evening with stuffed mushrooms then for the main course we enjoyed the Bauernplatte - Combo for Two (A generous platter with our German Bratwurst, Rote Bratwurst, Hackbraten, Kassler Kotelett and Pork Schnitzel served with Sauerkraut, Red Cabbage, German Fried Potatoes and Schwäbische Spätzle). The entree's also come with a cup of soup.

My husband quench his thirst with Warsteiner Dunkel beer while I enjoyed the German Margarita and listened to the live music while dining on the outdoor patio. 

Unfortunately we had no room left for dessert but we have had their strudels and bread pudding in the past and both are yummy bites of heaven.

Always a great time and fantastic food and service.

The last time I had AMAZING German food like this place was when I visited family in Jasper IN about 18 years ago.  The soup of the day was a cream of mushroom soup, and OMG, it was SOOOO good!  We had the Sample Sausage appetizer, the Schweizer Schnitzel, and the Kassler Kotelett.  OMG, the food was AMAZING!!!!  This was my husband's first time ever having German food, and he LOVED it.  We're looking forward to going back again real soon!

Ditto all the previous reviews, I've been to this place 3 times now and have never been disappointed.

This time I shared the Bartlett Pear and Black Forest sandwich.
And of course potato pancakes.
For dessert, we shared an apple strudel.

Absolutely Scrumptious!

I've had the Hefeweizen before...yummmm.

I love the new place, and can't wait to go again!
Some of the worst German food I've ever had.  The server was very nice though, and the pretzel was okay.

I have been to Haus Murphy's twice and both time I was very disappointed with their food.
Their Schnitzel was just horrible so was the Schweinebraten.
The owner should seriously send his cooks to Germany for a week so they will have a better idea on what to serve.
While the service and atmosphere is quite good I would not recommend unless you just going there for Beer.
This place is so quaint! The food is amazing. I am German and have been to Germany and the food is very close!

Visiting the Phoenix area and my friend who lives there suggests we try this place.  He seemed enthusiastic about it and I know that when a local gets that way about someplace in their backyard, it must be good.  It was.  It is tucked away along Glendale Blvd. and it is bigger than it looks on the outside.  It also has a dining patio that has a lot of flags hanging down over it. The interior looks like you have stepped into a diner in Germany or the Alps.  
 
I ordered the Jager Schnitzel and it was very tender and lots of flavor.  My wife ordered the Nurnberger Bratwurstchen and it seemed like a lot but she finished it.  I tried a bite and the sausage had a snap when you bit into it, was juicy and had a lot of flavor.  Everyone is our party was stuffed, but we still shared a slice of Bavarian chocolate cake!  

This restaurant was a fun new experience for us as we have never had German before and I can say I will be back when I am visiting the Phoenix area again.

Love Huas Murphy's!! The food is excellent! The staff is always friendly and welcoming. They make you feel like you're family! It does get pretty loud depending on what time you go but overall it's a really awesome and fun place!
Took a little long to get the food. I've been here for an hour and a half- the food took over an hour. Great quality, great beer, nice servers, but they just need to speed up a little.

What a special treat. Very rarely do you find an authentic German restaurant.... and a good one at that! I ordered the steak salad without cheese and the red cabbage. My mom ordered the jagerschnitzel and was amazing. The drinks we fun, a German margarita and the melon something... But the red cabbage was my favorite! It reminded me of my Omas. Beautiful gem, family friendly in the front, full lounge in the back.

Love this place.  My family is German and I have been to Germany.  This place is legit.  Great service, food, German beer selection etc.  love the Jager schnitzel, German potato salad and cabbage is delicious
Amazing food , old country recipes , a quaint Lil place nesting in downtown old Glendale.  My GF of 7yrs went there with me on our first date for lunch

We love German food and had heard this was one of the best.   It was okay......not the worse nor the best we have had but yes we might go back.  We both got the sauerbraten and red cabbage and the meat is so tender you can cut it with a fork.......and we did!  Red cabbage needed to be a little more 'tart' for us but realize that everyones recipe is different. Our waitress was very knowledgable about the beers and most helpful in explaining and answering our questions. Only complaint I have is the hostess. She asked if we wanted to sit outside, hot day so I said only if we can be in the shade. No shade - she she seats us in the bar area.   Had I realized this before - it was our first time there - I would have insisted that we were seated in the nice part of the restaurant. She was a little snippy when I said we should go inside due to the heat.  And yes we had reservations.  We will go back.......as the over all experience was good.

I haven't been to Germany but I have been to Haus Murphy's. Why does this matter? Haus Murphy's makes me feel like I haven't missed out on the great beer halls of Europe.

My first visit to Haus Murphy I was serenaded by a tubist (Duane) and an accordion player (Elmer). Both gents were wearing short lederhosen and alpine hats (complete with a feather!) Perhaps entertained by my slack jawed expression they asked for my name.  And so I heard the song "Good night Irene" as performed by a tuba and an accordion. These guys are here on Friday and Saturday nights, 6:30-8:30pm. They take requests!

You should come hAngry. The food is served in enormous sized portions. The Wiener Schnitzel is perfectly delivered. "But Irene. You haven't been to Germany!" Heck no. But I've been to Vienna and have gobbled my way thru many a schnitzel.  Haus Murphy's version is tenderly prepared, lightly fried in such a way you want to forget about the calories involved. 

I've had the good fortune to enjoy the indoor and outdoor spaces, in small, medium and large groups. The outside space is a wonderful venue to enjoy people watching. The indoor space readily accommodates larger parties. I would recommend coordinating in careful detail if your party is larger than ten. At my last visit for Int'l Supper Club the staffing was a little stretched for a party of our magnitude. We ended up walking to the bar to obtain our drinks, which wasn't really too much of an issue.

Haus Murphy's is a really fun place to visit and dine. Also, RSVP for holiday events as they fill up!
Good place for rich German food. Be prepared to work out an extra hour the next day to keep up your New Years resolution to lose weight. Prices are a bit steep but everything tastes good.

We went to Haus Murphy last night to celebrate a friends birthday.  We have been many times..The service was spot on...we love the German uniforms that they wear...the food is outstanding.  Portions are huge...enough for lunch today.

We had a variety of items from sausages to schnitzels.  Everything was excellent.  They even had a desert with a candle for our friend with the birthday.  To top it off, they sang Happy Birthday in German...Lovely evening

We had another enjoyable experience here tonight.  The food,  as usual,  was delicious. I had the Guiness Brats and my husband had Paprika Schnitzel.  Our server Carleen was a doll!  They had a special of 2 dinners plus dessert for $24.00.  The portions are large so we ended up getting to go boxes for part of our dinner and the desserts.  I'm sure the strudel dessert  will be delish for breakfast in the morning!

There is no better German Restaurant in all of Arizona. We first went here in Oktoberfest, where the set up long tables, and tents with a real German band, huge beer stein and German food, what fun.   The food and beer is old world good. The staff is happy and having as much fun as we were.

Wow!  Was this place awesome!  I had the meatloaf.. husband had schnitzel..
The server was so patient with us and made us feel special( thank you JImmy!)
What a great experience... who knew I loved German food?!?!  
We will be back!!

Several weeks ago I committed with a group of 40 people to attend the 2015 Oktoberfest at House Murphy (5739 W. Glendale Ave., Glendale, AZ 85301). Yesterday, on the day of the event, the organizer of our group received a confirmation phone call from them that ended with "Make sure everyone in your group has $10 cash for the entrance fee." This was the very first time it was mentioned!

To add this fee at the last minute, with no time to contact everyone, was a slimy, low-life method of gouging money.

BEWARE of this last-minute trickery at this mendacious establishment.

Heard about this place and was wanting to try it. The bad thing about it was it took 20 minutes from the time I was seated to a waiter to come and ask what I wanted to drink. On the positive side the waiter was friendly. I ordered the original German sausage. The potatoes were perfect to me the sausage was good. It came with a side of soup which was green bean and bacon. The soup was delicious even though I hate green beans but it tasted good so props to them on that. The atmosphere does bring out the German culture along with the music that is being played. If the wait time wasn't horrible then I would see why this would be a five star rating.

I went last night for the first time. I was very excited as I lived in Germany for five years and love German food. My companion and I tried the Sauerbraten and Beef Roulade. 
These are two of my favorite German dishes. I was sorely disappointed. The meat was tough and flavorless as was the Spatzle and Potato Dumpling. The Red Cabbage  was good but I've tasted just as good out of a can. The highlight of the meal was the Onion Soup. That was truly delicious. However, not worth the $45 bill for two people for just the entrees. The Service was excellent with no complaint there. However, I expected much more, especially from a restaurant that has been around as long as this one. If you want to try a truly excellent German restaurant go to The German Cafe in Sierra Vista. It will give you a taste of really authentic German cooking.

Everything my husband and I ordered was great!  I loved the Raspberry German Margarita, and I only had one, because I knew I could have had many and probably would have been dancing on the tables. 

The food was delicious, the atmosphere was lively, complete with a trombone and accordion group that played Old German folk songs, as well as took newer requests.  A little girl requested the song, "Let It Go," and the accordion player happily obliged.  

Apparently, Guy Fiery has showcased this restaurant on the Food Network, but we didn't know this until after we started looking over the menu.  Like I said, everything was delicious, and I'll be back when I visit Arizona again.

Sorry but I have to take it down a notch. We love this place because the food is phenominal, the atmosphere is friendly and they serve some of our favorites, like the german salad and schnitzel, but they have changed their menu. Green beans there were fantastic, and they traded them for boring mushrooms. They did have an unbelievable beef gulosh which is now beef and pork...I don't know what is up with all the changes, but why rattle your frequent customers by switching from perfection which is why we keep coming back? Oh, and if you haven't tried Schofferhauffer...its a grapefruit flavor beer that tastes like summer, fabulous.

Went for dinner, for the very first time last night. Our server was wonderful, she explained the different beers and food items to us. She checked back often once our food arrived to make sure we were enjoying ourselves. The food was over the top, never had German food before but know I know I like it!!

What happened to this place? Came here on 10/13/17 with my husband. We were carded outside the restaurant by security before we were allowed into the restaurant.

We ordered the stuffed mushrooms ($8.95) as an appetizer, and I ordered the paprika schnitzel ($14.95) while my husband got the schweinshaxen ($19.95). 

I have no idea what was going on with the service because various waiters and food runners came up to us, "is this your tea?" Nope. "Did you order this wine?" Nope again. "You ordered this beer?" Still no.

Our mushrooms came out in a heap on a paper AZ cardinals plate. It tasted fine but presentation looked like something you'd scoop onto your own plate at a backyard bbq.

A half hour after our appetizer came out, we were presented with meals that we didn't order, including some sort of bratwurst. We let the food runner know that it wasn't our order before he even set the food down. 

Our waiter double checked his pad and came back to let us know that he put in the wrong order. We waited another 30+ minutes for our food to come out. My husband's meal was served on a disposable black plastic plate and mine was served on another disposable AZ Cardinals plate. 

There was nothing done to remedy the mix up and the extra long wait for our food. Our waiter had to take off 4 different entrees on our bill that he brought over for us to sign. I had to flag down a waitress just to get a pen to for my husband to sign the check.

We're not driving down here again to eat here.

Been wanting to try Haus Murphys for several years now and finally made it to downtown Glendale,sorry to say we felt what we ordered was quite underwhelming, I had the Big Smoky Beef Brat with fried potatoes,first off the kraut was absolutely bland, have tasted better out of a jar! and was served maybe three tbs barely enough to lay the sausage on,maybe a good thing,the fried potatoes were mostly burnt and hard,must have been in the cooker the better part of the day. Even the salad served before was kind of sad. Wife had the chicken with a cream sauce that I tried that was rather good though we expected a plump breast not one that looks as it had been through a ringer washer but maybe that's the way German chicken is served . the the potatoes again were burnt and hard.Will say service was excellent.if we go back and right now that's a big if' we'll definitely try other items on the menu staying away from the fried potatos.
All in all for the prices they charge we were quite disappointed.
Great atmosphere, authentic German food. Unique German beers you can't get anywhere else. One of my favorite restaurants.

Wanted to try this place out but was turned away because my party wasn't big enough. (My wife and I) The explanation was that it was too busy. 

Very disappointing because I've been wanting to come here but now I'll never return.

A great place to enjoy fantastic German Bavarian food and beer . The quality is great and the recipes authentic. Atmosphere and service are a unique combination of Arizona friendliness and German rustic attitude.
It's was OK. A little overpriced. Potions were good, and the patio is nice. I will come back to try more dishes.
Bauern platter was very good. Red kraut is the best, wurst and schnitzel were perfect. Great service, too.

We went during Glendale Glitters.  Great beers, great band, good food, nice patio.  There was some odd interaction in the beginning where they didn't seem to want us to sit where we saw an empty table further away from the band, but that got straightened out somehow-I paid very little attention.
We all had different beers, and some pretzel bites and other things.  Everything was delicious.
The inside of the restaurant needs a little help, but I didn't see that it hurt business at all.
I had a good time, and am eager to go back.

Was staying in town on business and decided to check this place out because I saw it on DDD on food network.  Got the brat sampler and a side of spatzle.  The brat sampler was as expected, not super great but pretty good overall.  The spatzle wasn't as great as i was expecting and didn't seem to have much flavor at all in general.  Overall I kind of wish I would have tried the Schniztel but doubt I'll be trying this place out again.
Fun atmosphere, great service, & amazing food!

Wifey and I continued our quest this past Friday evening for a good German restaurant in Arizona.  I am pleased to report that Haus Murphy's is such and that we enjoyed our Jäger Schnitzel meals.  Wifey also ordered the super pretzel to go.  Previous comments have already extolled the virtues of Haus and our experience would tend to support the more positive ones.  We were greeted outside and quickly seated in the moderately busy inside seating.  Our server was fun and engaging.  Service was reasonably quick and correct.  Pork and vegatible soup came with dinner and was pretty good.  The Schnitzel covered almost half the plate and was crispy and tasty.  Life was good.  This is the best German food in Arizona (that we've been to so far).  And a shout out the live accordion music.  The music was spot on with lively toe-tapping beats - Roll Out the Barrel and other familiar drinking songs heard in the beer halls we've all been to.

Of course it's all relative.  I remember back in the day when we lived in Germany we would get cravings for, what else?  Mexican food!  Luckily, one of the local Gasthaus had Mexican night every Thursday.  Being from Arizona, I can tell you that although it wasn't the greatest, it did have some spiciness to the enchilades and came with beans, Spanish rice and a salsa, and it made us happy.  So it was the best Mexican in our area of Germany. 

And so, when we get those cravings for a taste of Germany and it's not Oktoberfest, we know where we can go until the next time we can go get the real deal.  Over there.

I love the food here, but the planning and service are atrocious.

First off, reservations don't mean what you think they do.  Make a reservation?  Plan to still wait and then get seated at a community table.

Secondly, they have too much going on.  Most of the year appears to feature a limited menu of one kind or another.  If you go there and it's an open menu day, try not to like the food too much, because it may be a year before you can have it again.

Finally, I've had more crappy service there than I've had good.  Servers have forgotten to bring a course, brought the wrong food, not checked back on us - you name it.

It's sad because the food here really IS good.  It's just so hard to get.
Love this place.  Stop in every time we are in Glendale.  Best German beer selection in the Valley.  Food is really good and they have great staff.

Just returned to try em out again. Jimmy took great care of us once again! Food and service hit it out the park so im officially  convinced this place is the real deal! Probably wont be back soon only because i gotta start dropping some pounds and this place aint gonna be no help.... however, if and when i allow a cheat day Haus Murphys will be on the short list for places to go stuff my face. This place is a gem!

WARNING:  New chef.  I've been coming here happily for years.  First of all, most of the menu is gone, along with the dishes that kept me coming.  I decided to try something new, the Goulash.  Very disapointed.  Even the spatzel was not up to par.   When I expressed this to the waitress, a "gee I'm sorry" was the extent of the response as she walked away.   Beer was as good as ever, but not enough to overcome the disapointing food.

We wanted to celebrate the beginning of Oktoberfest and decided to treat ourselves to some German beers and German food at Haus Murphy's on a Saturday early evening. We requested to sit in the bar area because we find it more lively than the restaurant area (and on this particular visit there was a polka band playing in the bar area).

To start, we had their giant pretzel. It was baked to perfection. Then, we elected to split their dinner platter for two (the one on the regular menu, not the one on the specials menu, can't remember the exact name). The platter included soup for each of us, which was a creamy chicken florentine - I am usually not a chicken florentine fan but it was really tasty. The platter was perfect to fulfill both of our Sausage and Schnitzel cravings. We also loved the potatoes, weird noodle things (?) and cabbage and sauerkraut that accompanied it.

We finished off with the Black Forest dessert, which was the only part of our meal that was a disappointment - it was dry and tasted like it had maybe been in the refrigerator too long.

We loved hearing the band play while we were there and were extremely satisfied with our Oktoberfest dining experience.

This place is awesome! If you love good German food Haus Murphy's is as good as it gets. We always take advantage of the outdoor Biergarten (ask for Shannon's section, she's the best!) and the atmosphere is wonderful, even in the blistering Phoenix heat. If you go on the weekend you should definitely take advantage of the wonderful tuba and accordion music with a great draft beer.

Also, the food never disappoints. The Jäger Schnitzel is a favorite, along with the ham shank (but you have to catch it on special). Don't miss the Giant Bavarian Pretzel and the stuffed mushrooms are some of the best we've ever had. The BIG Stuffed Cabbage Roll and Schweizer Schnitzel are also some fan favorite. Finally, don't forget to try the Sauerkraut Cake. It's wonderful, especially for chocolate lovers. 

This place is definitely a family favorite and not to be missed on any trip to the Phoenix area. Prost!!

Wow the sausage selection here is killer! When we arrived, a German style band was playing. Unfortunately, they were replaced by an excellent female singer.... Just doesn't do the mood. Definitely got to order a boot.. A very cute large glass of beer that require a debit card to order. Our favorite sausage was the kilometer... Large, smokey, delicious. We also like the spicy rote and sweet Guinness sausage. I don't normally like sauerkraut but I loved the sauerkraut! Subtle, tasty, keeps me coming back for more! The beer was great also. I'm a dark stout lover so the celebrator was perfect! We came here because it was a tradition... For being my first time, I would come back. It is a very cool, casual ambiance with staff dressed in kinda traditional garb. Give this place a try, just don't come here for a special occasion except ocktberfest!
Great meals - great service. We were very well taken care of and food was in great portions. You gotta have the pretzel  !!!!

We attending the closing night of Glendale Glitter and arrived at 4:15pm to eat an early dinner. We had a party of 6 adults, 2 kids and an infant (that remained in his car seat the entire dinner). The place was busy but to our delight, were seated immediately in the back bar area. This is when things started to get rough. Our waitress arrived approximately 15-20 minutes after we were seated to see if she could start is out with some waters. When I asked about the beer menu, she seemed confused... But I thought maybe because that came further along in her checklists of things she was required to accomplish. Once I had the beer menu in have I began asking simple questions about the beer. Like..."what are the different beers comparable to?". This is when rough turned worse for our waitress. She explain that the first three beers were "like Coors light" and the last two beer so were "dark beers". The night only got worse. I'll give you some of the quotes... When asked what the sides (listed in German) were... The response was "I have no idea". When asked what type of meat was in the stuffed cabbage... Again "I have no idea" followed quickly by the statement " I am so bad at this"...I believe she was referring to her job as a waitress.  I actually felt incredibly bad for our waitress. She's just didn't care at all about that job making it painful for both her and the patrons. The food was good. Not great. The best thing we had all night was the spicy sausage cheesy bread appetiser. It was awesome.
Plenty of food but more important to me was that every bite was wonderful.  Service was excellent,  friendly & attentive.  Had enough leftovers for 2 more servings!  Can't wait to go back.
Great atmosphere, inside and outside in the beer garden.  Food is incredible!!  Great German beer selection.  A fantastic meal and fun atmosphere.  Highly recommend reservations.

On a rainy day, this was the perfect place for a big lunch! Service was good, staff was welcoming and the food was perfectly cooked. 

We shared the plate for two and started with the house cheese, which was all flavorful and just the right size for a large meal. Overall, well worth the drive and I can't wait for a sunny day to enjoy on their patio with a liter of beer and a warm pretzel!

Haus Murphy is the only authentic German bar/restaurant in the west valley.  They have 10 taps (Weihenstephaner Hefe-Weissbier, Franziskaner Weissbier, Spaten Optimator, Spaten Marzen, Warsteiner, and a couple more...).

Service is usually good and it has a very charming, relaxed atmosphere with German decor.

Mature customer base also... which is to my liking.

Had heard this place had received national recognition for being the best German food...it took them over 1 hour to get our dinner..they forgot my 5 year old niece's order and when they brought her the hot dog it was a shrivilled  up canned cocktail weinie... The food was tasteless..the only thing I can say that was good was the accordion player..never eat here again..

The food is just so darn good here and the ambience is pretty fun as well. Delicious schnitzels, sausages, wursts, and the roulade - ridiculously good. Our server was cheerful and helpful - thanks for the advice on the Kilometer sausages (best ever!) The beer was ice cold and the oompah music was a blast as well. Can't imagine a better place for German food.

Only heard good things about this place and finally decided to check them out..  We were there on a Sunday and they had a pretty cool band called "Behind the Badge" who were raising money for a charitable cause.   I would have given 5 stars but the service was very slow and they did not seem to happy to be serving us outside.  We generally had to get up and walk inside to ask them for food/drinks.  With that out of the way, the food and drinks made up for the poor service!  Tried the soft pretzels(they were out of the large pretzels so I had two smaller ones)  It was a lot of food and seemed somewhat average but not bad.  My aunt got an order of the potato pancakes which were outstanding! They were accompanied with sour cream and applesauce which added to the flavor.  I'm a real big fan of German beers so I had a couple of Dunkels which went really well with my appetizer.  When it was time to order dinner, my waiter recommended the Chicken Cordon Bleu Schnitzel which was actually pretty solid.  Later I tried a bite of the pretzel schnitzel which was even better!  At this point I'm a fan of the food and would recommend it just because of the food and German beer on tap.  The service was rather poor except for the bartender who went out of his way to make us some unusual shots.  I'm fairly confident they were spread a little thin so I would like to try them again on a weeknight or Saturday.   will definitely check them out again and will be back to try the veal schnitzel and some of the sausages.  Cool place!

Sunday was my friend Dave's anniversary, sadly his wife passed away in December.  We had a memorial for her Saturday night, and Sunday Dave invited me to dinner for his anniversary, not that I'm as good looking as Kris was.  We decided on Papadeaux, but I'd forgotten that this week was Mardi Gras and they were packed.  Dave was lamenting the passing of Felsen Haus when I remembered that there's a great German restaurant in Glendale.  Having never been there before, I didn't have a clue what the name was, but Yelp, searching for German and Glendale, led me right there.  And after a quick call, we found out there was no wait and headed across town.

Dave served in the Army in Germany, and he really liked his meal.  He found the menu very impressive and enjoyed flexing his German language muscles with the staff.  His schnitzel was not the precise one he was looking for, but he enjoyed it nonetheless.

Me, I had the Tirol chicken, and was pleased.  I am anti-fungus and was able to avoid the mound placed on my plate, I should have asked if they were incorporated in what I thought was a sauce or were on the side and could have had them removed.

Sadly, I'm not a beer drinker (yet: we're going to Europe next year, that could change) and didn't have one.  Dave had a half liter of something or other and was quite pleased, said it was definitely like he had when he was based there.

Definitely recommended.  Very good food, excellent staff.  Well worth the trip.

Wow Saturday is busy with Glendale Glitters.  This is our go to spot for German food.  It is fun with a great atmosphere.  The food here is worth trying.  They have great sides to go with their meals.  The chocolate sauerkraut cake is so perfect.  You should go and enjoy the food and ambiance.

This was my wife and I first time to eat at Hus Murphy's. She order the gouloush and I had the stuffed cabbage. I must say that I wasn't impressed. The food was bland. It tasted like it was watered down. The service was excellent.

Given the dearth of German restaurants in the greater Phx area, this is about as good as it gets.

Had the sausage sampler.  The krakauer wurst was pretty unique.  The bratwurst was good too, but brats usually have a pretty low bar to clear to be good.

Had the Schweizer Schnitzel as a main course.  Very good.

The meal came with a cup of soup of the day, which in this case was mushroom.  Very good.

You can't eat ambiance/decor so I generally don't care about things like that but if the owners have a spare dollar or two they may want to paint the place and replace the drop ceiling.  Neither of those things will keep me away but they may want to look into those things.

What a fun place. I loved the vibe, music, and food. I am not usually a fan of German food but I enjoyed my Original Brat meal. The potatoes are awesome! My server was fine but he really lacked personality. The gal on the way out made up for it. She talked to me about the history of the restaurant and was most gracious! I have to say, and my friends will laugh at this comment, I enjoyed the Accordion player. He is quite good!

I was not that impress maybe because I had my expectations to high. They don't have accesible parking we had to parked at the street and we were lucky and found a spot.   The service is ok I think the waitress assumes you know what the dishes are.  The food was just ok I mean it's worth to try for your self and find out if you like it or not but I don't think I'll go back for food maybe for beer or the pretzel because I couldn't try those .  I got the beef  schnitzel with paprika and it was just ok I think I rather have the country fried stake  at IHOP.  The potatoes were good though.  But just go try for your self!!

I certainly don't understand the hype over this place.  That's strike 2 for you Guy Fieri (#1 is Chino Bandido, bleh).  The layout of this restaurant is very strange, but I kind of like that they separate the large groups from the smaller groups of diners.  The staff, especially our server, was extremely accommodating and put up with our certainly frustrating antics of playing board games on the dinner table.  

I was pretty hungry when we got here, so i decided to order something on the heavier side and went with the gnocchi.  The gnocchi were lightly pan fried and then drowned in a ridiculously rich cheese/cream sauce and sprinkled with chunks of pancetta and a handful of wild mushrooms.  The mushrooms tasted really weird for some reason and the sauce was too tangy.  It just didn't complement the dish the way it should have.  I did however, eat every last bit of pancetta.  Yum!  I saw a slice of German Chocolate Cake (no, it is not German in the least bit) being served to someone at another table and I gave the puppy dog eyes until we ordered it.  It came out looking rather impressive, but it went down tasting rather dull.  It was dry and lifeless and the only good part, the coconut pecan icing, was severely lacking.

Well, I won't be back here, especially after most of my companions were less than enthused with their meals instead.  Oh well, I guess that will make everyone else happy.

My husband and I have been wanting to try this place for awhile, it was worth the wait. My husband lived in Germany and I have visited on numerous occasions. The food was very authentic, loved the beers on tap! We can't wait to go back again.

Love the giant pretzel and the Kilometer is my favorite dish.
  I am a huge fan of the sauerkraut and the Black forest cake as well.
The experience, however, varies greatly depending on your server.  The first time we went, our server spoke German with us and others and he made a very fun atmosphere. We shared conversation with the other diners and shared food as well.  We looked forward to going back.
 The next two times we went, both servers seemed very preoccupied, looking everywhere but at us, "forgetting" to bring us something, not refilling drinks.  The place wasn't busy at all, they just seemed not to care about service.
  Hubby didn't like Hackbraten and noticed that the carpets really need to be cleaned.

So as I am close to half German, I saw this place on Triple D on the food network, and while visiting family this summer, I talked them all in to going. we started with the sausage sampler, and the house soup that comes with the meal. mmmmmm good. My brother in law and I split the Bauernplatte - Combo for Two which has German Bratwurst, Spicy Bratwurst, Weisswurst, Kassler Kotelett and Pork Schnitzel served with Sauerkraut, Red Cabbage, German Fried Potatoes and German Potato Salad. man by the end, we were stuffed, and still had potato salad to take home. Our wives ordered Hühner (Chicken) Schnitzel, and of all things the gnocchi, which was pretty darn good. I would love to go back tho this place, the ambiance and the service were great, and the food was amazing in my opinion. 
The topper of it all was the ice cold authentic German beer on tap. 3 kinds of Spaten, Weihenstephan Hefeweizen, Warsteiner, and others. They actually have a beirgarten or beer garden to sit outside and drink in, It was summer when we went so the 109 degree heat at 7:00 kept us inside. If you are in town, give it a try, Near the Cardinals stadium, would be great for after game celebration.
